commentBody: Back to Monday-level for the rest of the week, I guess
Just slightly under my Monday average. Nice puzzle, but way too easy.
Makes for a quick Thursday when the revealer is an obvious first answer. Not a tough puzzle this week, but sometimes an easier Thursday is a fun change.

The last Monday puzzle with a rebus was August 6, 2018. It would have been fine to hold this one for February 23, 2026.

SRSLY!
Yesterday took me maybe 3x as long as today. Are rebuses allowed on Wednesday?
Much too easy for a Thursday.

Even taking it a little slow, bc I was distracted, I still finished in less than half my average.  

Agree with the general sentiment that it was overly easy for a Thursday puzzle.

Took me a good while to catch on to the theme ‚Äî always a good sign. And lots of the clues and answers felt especially fresh. Nice to see BIOS without any mention of its shortness in the clue. (I would like to see no mention of such info mid-to-late-week when it's the form of the word, like "bios", that everyone uses. (Here "everyone" doesn't means "everyone", of course.) I tackled the "Up and ___" clue unawares, overlooking the physics connection and filling in AT 'eM instead. I won't even mention the joke about the lesser of two weevils.
PB for Thursday, more of a Tuesday puzzle at most.

Such a fun example of ‚Äúguess the revealer‚Äù, with only a tinge of disappointment that it wasn‚Äôt somehow the ‚Äúlesser of two trig functions‚Äù.

Then I got a laugh when I got to the colored EGGS.  I had EG - S, and brain instantly piped up EGOS!  Can you imagine: a selection of differently colored egos, in the seasonal aisle in spring? (Mine is purple, and it is year round.)

I'm not sure if you all are under editorial direction to make these easier, but please go and look at some of your Thursday-Friday-Saturday puzzles from the before times (I'm almost done with 2013 - they're diabolical, and let me know it is not, in fact, that I am too skilled). 

It was nice when I could learn new things from esoteric crossword puzzle answers, when solving a Saturday puzzle felt like an accomplishment. As my streak approaches its second year, it feels more like dead weight than something to be proud of.
Seems easy for a Thursday puzzle. Caught the gimmick rather quickly so I finished in much less than my average time

Usually I expect a rebus to make a puzzle more challenging, but here it quickly became apparent that all the circles contained the sin rebus, and a couple of crosses made it clear that the shaded squares had sin too.  With so many free letters, and an obvious revealer, there wasn‚Äôt much mystery to the puzzle.  Not what I was hoping for.
Thursday? No. Tuesday. Sometimes a puzzle can be quick and fun. This was just easy. I wait for Thursday to even do the puzzles. Disappointing. Sorry.
New PB.
Maybe without the shaded squares and circles this would have put up some resistance. As it was, I just filled in the answers and only slowed down to hit the rebus key. Bummer :(
I enjoyed your puzzles. I am always baffled by the negative comments.
It's fine. I was embarrassingly  slow to catch the exact trick of the rebus but otherwise the puzzle fell into place.

A little surprised everyone is calling it Monday-Tuesday level.  I finished faster than my Thursday average but not anywhere close to Monday-Tuesday speed.  More like an easy Wednesday (Especially compared to yesterday that was full of Naticks).

Fun puzzle though.

Well, that was quick! Fun, but not particularly challenging. The revealer was cute. I usually expect having to work at a Thursday, but this pretty much filled itself.

Thanks, John.
Finally a Thursday puzzle at my level üòÅ
If you're looking for puzzles that are of the difficulty and quality of the pre-2020 NYT, where do you go? This one used to be the gold standard, and I'm not sure where to get my fix now
8:04 without really even trying. Theme was obvious from the first clue. Please, please can we go back to clever, tricky puzzles?

Whoever decided to run this on a Thursday should be cruci-fined, or sent to SINg-(SIN)g. 

There is that scene in Master and Commander where Jack Aubrey is telling a joke at the Captain's Table, punch line: "...the lesser of two weevils!" The books (O'Brian) are great fun to read, good historical accuracy, you learn a lot about seafaring, and the characters are all well drawn. Movie's not bad either. 

I wouldn't say paupers are necessarily penniless. They might still be pennied, even after being thoroughly nickeled & dimed. I would say a better answer these days to [Penniless one] would be US Mint. 

Beyond the puzzle's lightning quickness what is more disappointing to me is the lack of wit and misdirection in the cluing/fill. Gas units -- GALLONS was typical in that regard. I wanted to shake the puzzle by its lapels and shout loudly in its face, "Cmon, make me bleed a little!"

Like many of the other early commentators here, I am getting seriously annoyed. It takes more than a rebus and a clever theme idea to make a decent Thursday puzzle. Ok, it was a cute idea and the theme fill was relatively interesting and well chosen. And I will even grant that for some themes if you get the first one you can fill in the others more easily, that‚Äôs the nature of some themes. But for heaven‚Äôs sake why does the majority of the clueing have to be a Monday level? Seriously does three quarters of the puzzle have to be gimmes?
I just finished a Saturday archive puzzle‚ÄîJune 4th 2016‚ÄìByron Walden/Brad Wilbur. Took me an hour and a half but I finally cracked it (except for an Natick at the end that I could have potentially cracked as well). I‚Äôm not saying it was a perfect puzzle but at least it had respect for the solver‚Äôs intelligence. And I know this is a Thursday, not a Saturday. But still‚Äîis the  New York Times readership that much less intelligent than 10 years ago, or do the editors just think we are?
Sorry for the rant, and if you want to go off on me for being an elitist have at it. But the juxtaposition of solving these two puzzles just really set me off.
I'd call this the lesser of Tue...sday. Definitely not a Thursday puzzle.
So far I've spent more time completing Monday's puzzle than any other this week; I'm confused.
I really liked this one! It was a fun rebus.

Early comments expressing a lot of big feelings on the easiness of this one.

I‚Äôd like to say, first, I enjoyed it quite a bit and thought it was clever.

And second, this puzzle certainly wasn‚Äôt hard, but I thought it was fairly standard Thursday difficulty for a Monetization Era puzzle.
Easy but fun! Easier than Wednesday‚Äôs for me!
Is it too late to get a new SSN?  Mine has been a real beast.
It's been a while since I've done a Thursday puzzle and was pleased that this one included rebuses. Those always yield a little moment of delight for me!
My game completed before the puzzle was finished. The circled SIN in RESIN and BUSINESS INSIDERS was still just an S. I got the happy sound, timer stopped, and I can no longer edit. A bug?
There must be things other than TEEs that you can buy at a concert, but when I see "souvenir" in a clue I know where it's going.

After tripping up on Wednesday I'll take a faster than average Thursday solve. So yes even I found easier today but no complaints about the gimmes. I think it's more a progression leading up to Fri, Sat and Sun zingers. SINgling out as a conspiracy theory to sell more subscriptions? At a buck 39/month the numbers don't add up.
SIN is also the three letter airport for Singapore which I'm looking forward to visiting next week.

Just wanted to say this, but I do agree with a lot of you. This puzzle was EZ-PZ. Once you get one, it's just a big ol' fill-in-the-blanks theme. It was just like the Groundhog Day puzzle. It was kind of neat, but it got extremely easy from the get-go. 3 stars. ‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è
Keep it up, y'all! ;)
SINful!

commentBody:
I missed the report card which relegated me to remedial Thursdays.

Yesterday I did Feb 10, 2022's Thursday.

I dare anyone to tell me it's not at least 100% more difficult.

Fine...keep the banal fill if you must conscript new solvers with easier late-week puzzles.

But ladies and gentlemen of the puzzle department...

By all that is good and holy...

At LEAST zhoosh up the clueing!

Speaking of dumbing down I had a fun flashback from the constructor‚Äôs name. Anyone remember ‚ÄúThe Newlywed Game‚Äù from the ‚Äò60s/‚Äò70s? The host was Bob Eubanks. I remember one show in particular. The question was addressed to the wives first‚Äî‚ÄúIn your neighborhood, ladies‚Äîin your neighborhood‚Äîin what direction does the sun rise?‚Äù I actually found the clip: https://www.tiktok.com/@jamaalthecashier1/video/7345241061884759338 This was the same show that used ‚Äúwhoopie‚Äù as a euphemism. Now that was quality television‚Ä¶

Rebuses usually make me sigh because I find them engaging but challenging‚Ä¶this was way too easy for Thursday. I‚Äôm not a master but if I can finish Thursday in under 30 something is off‚Ä¶but it felt ok since yesterday was very hard for a Wednesday ‚Äî to me at least.

I just listened to the latest episode of NYT's The Daily podcast (Can A.I. Already Do Your Job?)

Sounds like if it can't already, very soon you'll be able to ask Anthropic's Claude (next-generation AI assistant) something like, "Make a set of clues for today's puzzle that is as difficult as a Thursday from 2007"

And in the near future, you should be able to ask Claude, "Make me a puzzle as challenging as a NYT Saturday from 2002, heavy on the word-play and with few proper nouns..."

I don't wish for human creators and editors to be out of work, but if AI can custom-design me a Thursday that takes longer than 10 minutes to solve...
I see a lot of comments complaining the puzzle was too easy. But I came here to say I enjoyed the theme and thought it was very cute.

The clue for 29D reminded me of an incident that happened when I first moved away from home.  Back then, one could ask Ma Bell for a phone number that was relatively easy to remember.  As soon as the number was assigned to me, I began getting frequent panicked ‚Äúwrong numbers‚Äù in the wee hours of the morning.  Turns out that my phone number was only one digit different from the local VD clinic (as they were called at the time).  Fed up, I called Bell to ask to have my number changed, which they did.  The very next day, I got a phone call at 1:00 am from someone trying to reach the VD clinic.  I asked the caller how he got my number.  The caller said he dialed my old number and got a recording that said, ‚ÄúThat phone number has been changed to xxx-xxxx‚Äù, which was my new phone number.  I had mistakenly agreed with Bell to have call forwarding! ü§™

I agree with everyone who thought the cluing terribly easy for a Thursday, but I still think credit and gratitude are due to Mr. Ewbank for the conceit and construction which I, for one, thought were awe-inspiring. (Yes, I'm always awed by talents I don‚Äôt have, which is why I enjoy crosswords so much. Constructors never cease to amaze me!) For conjecture's sake, it seems to me that the cluing was maybe made easier to balance out the presence of rebuses. That said, when the rebuses are repetitive, I'm of the opinion that more challenging cluing would be a better fit for a Thursday. In any case, I love me a Thursday puzzle and this one was no different. Added to that, it lit up the musical synapses in my brain: Bill Withers with "USE ME" (one of my favorite turn-up-the-bass songs of all time) - https://youtu.be/NuYDKzky4z0?si=t6SvsWzCOm5bAbur And [Take THAT] with "Back For Good" - https://youtu.be/N2ICtCO8TCw?si=94eo2FBtPVvOm-6g Thank you, Mr. Ewbank!

This one was very pleasant, but pleasant is far too lesser.  I wanted something that caused my teeth to clamp, perspiration to pop out on my brow, massive sighs from so deep inside they cause the candle flames to flutter, and groans of belated recognition.  And no, I'm not talking about our daily news reports.  

I wanted an evil, Thursday kind of puzzle, to make me forget all that for more than a few minutes, a puzzle so engaging that I was happy to spend at least an hour on it.

I know there's always the week-end, but that's a long time to wait.

A nice Tuesday or Wednesday puzzle, I think. I don't know if it's just me getting better, but the puzzles have seemed far less challenging recently. The only puzzles that stump are filled with random trivia or arcana. It's been a while since we had a difficult, and CLEVER, puzzle.

I have to reluctantly agree that this was a too easy puzzle, especially for Thursday.  The obvious circles for the rebus, the shaded squares also holding the rebus answer, and the same rebus for every one, while making for a humorous theme, just makes the solve that much simpler.

I give up on what to do about this problem.  I originally thought the progressive design through the week was a good compromise on making some for the beginners, some for the old hands.  But that seems to be breaking down, in that even the toughest puzzles just aren't enough for a lot of people here, even me included, maybe, as I get better.

Sigh.  Why can't things be like they were in the good old days?
Hoping for a challenging Friday and Saturday ahead

Ok, so I just established a new personal best streak (adhering to my very strict no lookups, cheats or hints policy) at 62.  If it weren‚Äôt for a slap the forehead mistake 63 puzzles ago, my streak would stand at 81.  No false modesty here, I‚Äôm proud of the streak and where I‚Äôve come from when first taking on the challenge of NYT crossword puzzles after previously limiting myself to the far easier local newspaper puzzle here in Vancouver (for those interested, the newspaper is The Vancouver Sun).  However, proud as I may be, I‚Äôm questioning the quality of the streak: the past few months of crosswords have either been easier than the typical puzzle of the previous 5 years (or so), or I‚Äôve legitimately gotten better.  I‚Äôd like to believe the latter, but suspect the former.  FWIW, when my previous best of 61 ended, it was a Sam Ezersky puzzle that broke the streak.  Im certain in saying there have been no puzzles as challenging as the one produced by that (notorious?) constructor, but I‚Äôd dare say the average puzzle has been easier this time round also.  Thoughts?

I hate to be that annoying ‚Äúlook how fast I am!‚Äù commentator. 

So you better look away now.  

13 minutes for a Thursday rebus.  It‚Äôs lent.  We need to atone!

8/6/14 nearly made me cry and that was a Wednesday puzzle. Highly recommend if you want to be tortured or pay some crossword penance. 

A sacred lent to all.

Oh my, about an hour ago, it's now midnight or thereabouts on Thursday, I went to the comments for the Wednesday puzzle because that darn it puzzle took me all day, on and off. I just couldn't get rolling with it, but chipped away, and little by little, finally got it done!
Now, I'm here to report, lol, Thursday's puzzle, completed!
I do not mind a tough puzzle, the mind needs a good work out too, and Wednesday's was fine, but perhaps the Thursday puzzle was just a tad too easy. I mean, when I finish a later week NYT crossword in 30 minutes? What is up with that!
Anyway, fast, but fun nonetheless.
Have a good night, or a good day, wherever you are.

...

This would have been a fine Tuesday, with its direct clueing, utter lack of misdirection and simple theme.

But a *Thursday*?

C'mon!

I came straight to the comments after finishing this puzzle ‚Äî I enjoyed it but was it Thursday tough? It took me 3x the amount of time to finish this week‚Äôs Wednesday and it took me about the same amount of time as this week‚Äôs Monday (which was slow for me but nevertheless shouldn‚Äôt be that close to a Thursday time). That being said, I did get a Thursday PR ‚Ä¶ but does it count?
Or sometimes the lesser of two weevils ...
People - if you want a harder Thursday puzzle, please submit one.  The NYT can only work with what they are given.  I enjoyed this puzzle.
Loved the theme!

I hate to pile on, but‚Ä¶ you know something‚Äôs wrong when at this point in the night, there are zero complaints about the presence of a rebus.

It‚Äôs almost like this was a Thursday primer: See Jack fill in the shaded squares. See Jack squeeze those same letters into a circle. Fill, Jack, fill!

I‚Äôm so sorry, Mr. Ewbank. I have nothing but praise for your abilities, but Jane, Spot and I think the editors did you wrong.

Almost a great puzzle. Only one I had trouble with was 34 Across which to me had to be STOLE until I got through all the crossings. Still not loving the answer as I don‚Äôt think it‚Äôs a good clue/answer pairing.
Did Wednesday and Thursday get switched

To add to the chorus of‚Äúit‚Äôs getting easier - it is it just me?‚Äù ‚Ä¶

I always start to solve every puzzle by going through the Across clues and seeing if i can finish the puzzle with those alone. Sometimes on a Monday or even a Tuesday i manage it. I finish the whole thing without ever seeing a Down clue. Today, i very nearly managed it‚Ä¶ on a Thursday! If it hadn‚Äôt been for the pesky Pecos River, i would have done it, in about 30 minutes. This is really unheard of. 

Lovely puzzle though, no complaints!
Well, it was easy for a Thursday but also clever.  I enjoyed my little epiphanies and the smooth solve.  With puzzles, I just like to take them as they come.

About six years ago I needed to have the wordplay article open while I worked any crossword. Today I didn‚Äôt open it until I was finished!  The past few Thursdays have not been hideous. I feel like I‚Äôve reached a level where the Th puzzles are still challenging but fun and accessible. I haven‚Äôt made up my mind about Saturday puzzles though. I think solving 6/7 per week suits me just fine. Thanks for an entertaining puzzle!!
Easy but great fun‚Ä¶and clever!

Oopsie!  The NYT accidently ran a puzzle that was meant for Highlights magazine.  Hopefully, the real Thursday puzzle will come up later.  

I anxiously await it's arrival.
Great fun. Clever rebus. Loved the aha moment connecting the revealer with the rebus circles. And it was ok that the rest of the puzzle was so accessible.

I agree with all the far-too-easy comments, although I'll say that noobs should get a thrown bone occasionally.

As an antidote, and an education, try what I've been doing for a few weeks: Go back to the earliest puzzle in the archive (1993?) and just start working your way forward. It's a binge-worthy experience.   A couple of thoughts: Yes, they *were* more difficult back then. And I'm an oldster. The ancient cultural references didn't throw me nearly as much as the clever (opaque?) clueing and construction - and fewer, or different emus.  Some of them are ungodly tough.

  Second, they were far less strict about sequential hardness (there are some killer Tuesdays) and rebus-appropriate days.  Trends seem to have become rules for many of us.

   Finally, some of the cultural references are a hoot. How much I've forgotten or repressed.  Spiro!  An Ollie that doesn't refer to skateboards. All those crooners! Bing and Dean and Perry.  Supreme courters Hugo and Thurgood.  Have fun!

["____ does it!"]

["____ as pie!"]

[____ chair]

["____ come, ____ go!"]

Came to say how I appreciated today after struggling mightily yesterday but I see that‚Äôs not the vibe so I‚Äôll see my way out.
I'm not gonna say it because I'm sure somebody else will, but I will say today's time was 45% less than average and yesterday's time was 65% more than average.

I guess people are too botherred/pleased by the ease of the puzzle, to be concerrned with WHIRRS. I've ever only seen it spelled "whir," and ngram confirrms that, in fact, "one-r whir" is the more common form, although "two-r whirr" outstripped it for most of the 19th c. 

Perr the OED, there's also a form "quhirr," using that weirrd Scottish spelling. Also, it probably derrives from Old Norse, brought when the Danelaw whirred into Northerrn England, and not simple onomatopoeia, which is what would have ocurrred to me.

In summation, "whir" is the sound a Tibetan priest's prayer wheel makes as it goes around; "whirr" is the sound a herrd of camelids make as they race through the Andes.

Last night, my Partner and I watched the 1961 film *Mothra*, and it could be said that "whir(r)" was the sound Mothra's wings made, as she destroyed Tokyo and New Kirk City.

If you thought this was a super easy puzzle for a Thursday, you're in good company.  From xwstats.com:

üåé  Global Stats

74% solved much faster (>20%) than their Thursday average.
üê¢8% of users solved slower than their Thursday average.
2% solved much slower (>20%) than their Thursday average.

My personal calendar from xwstats indicates that 11 of the 19 days so far this month, I have solved more than 20% faster than my average for the day, with only one day (Sat. the 7th) when I solved more than 20% slower than my average.

That is in stark comparison with January, when the numbers were reversed, with 12 days more than 20% slower, and only 2 days more than 20% faster.  

Given the fact that I'm doing everything a little slower these days than a few years ago, it's not surprising when I type slower, think slower, and just move slower.  What is surprising is when puzzles consistently take me astonishingly little time to complete.

At least, with the new system, reading the comments is slower.
Fun. I think we need to bring back the tricky Thursdays that would result in 1000 comments.

Well, I'm feeling for John Ewebank.  Here he came up with a sweet theme idea and expertly crafted a grid to showcase it.  

Absolutely, complain away about its unsuitability for the day it landed on -- that's what this forum is for, to express sincere reactions -- but also tip the constructor when deserved, giving credit where credit is due.

I can‚Äôt decide which is whirrs:

having TOUGHNUT in *this* puzzle,

or not cluing RANK as [Noisome].
At last, a fun, enjoyable Thursday with a straightforward (or straighdown) rebus. Thank you, creator!
This was a fun one. Not difficult, but a good intro for someone who wants to learn how to solve a rebus puzzle.

Not a TOUGH NUT to crack,
but a sweet puzz.

My dad,
who was as gentle as a lamb,
(and the reason I love the NYTXW 
and football),
would watch the Bears 
play *any*other team and say,

"Ooh CC! They're cruuusin' for a bruuuisin'!"

Thanks for the help today, Dad.
I know you're grinning wide over that one.
I've been renting gluttony and sloth recently. I'm a lessee of two evils.

I love the first-class constructor‚Äôs mind that came across the everyday phrase LESSER OF TWO EVILS, immediately (I imagine) wondered if a puzzle theme could be made with it, then came up with this primo idea with its perfect punchline.  Bravo, sir!

The theme not only does its job well, but it also gives the puzzle freshness, with all four theme answers being NYT debuts.  Not only did John have to juggle grayed squares, circles, and rebuses, but he got those theme answers to fit symmetry, and on top of all this, he filled the box with a clean answer set.  Bravo again!

I enjoyed coming across lovely answers ‚Äì WHIRRS, BLIP, TOUGH NUT, BONSAI ‚Äì during the fill-in, and I chef-kissed when I uncovered the revealer.

I liked the liquid-y subtheme: ARK, KEG, SHOWER, SOAKED, LEECH, THIRST, GALLONS, SEABEDS.  As well as the HISS subtheme, with seven answers containing double SS‚Äôs.  

Much sweetness in the box today, and thank you for sparking my day, John!

It wasn't hard to guess what the comments were going to look like today.

I'm new enough that the difficulty of various days is incidental in a way for me.

For evidence of the trend, I had one gold star in my first 16 attempts at Thursday and that took until attempt no. 13. Since then I have 4 in a row. I couldn't possibly have gotten that much better 4 weeks ago.

(I still don't like the rebus thing)
(now ducking away).
Nice theme, presented in a clever Thursday-esque manner. Sadly, the cluing was pretty much at a kindergarten level, which  kept me from really enjoying this puzzle. Oh well.

I started at the top and just went Across and Down and with nary a pause filled in the entire puzzle, even Eric BANA (Worst Pick Ever for his role as Henry VIII in "The Tudors"--not even the right color of hair and eyes even if he had had any skill as an actor...or was it the director's fault?)  

Okay, maybe I got up on the wrong side of the bed this morning?  At 5:30.  Because today is the Big Sale Day.  In a good cause.

Nice! Kind of easy for a Thursday, but fun.

I came here expecting to see the normal complaints about a rebus,
...and found none!

It only dawned on me now ‚Äî duh ‚Äî that people who enjoy crosswords enough to comment on them are mostly masochists. 

I liked the puzzle.
This was fun! Loved the theme. Figured out it was a rebus with no help! Go me! Lots of good fill. Thanks, John! Y‚Äôall have a wonderful day!

might it be an improvement

primary disappointment, many days.

Slowest Monday ever.

OMG a new best! Must have been squarely in my wheelhouse.

I miss the rebus puzzles...the real ones, without the circles to indicate where the rebus goes, accompanied by shaded squares that spell out exactly what the rebus is. The ones where each rebus was different. The ones that required some real effort to crack...but that feeling when you did crack it, and the puzzle started to yield, was wonderful. Those were my favorites, but I think they're gone for good now, and I don't know of any other source for them now.

I liked the puzzles that outrageously broke the rules, like the one that had the answer's direction turn ninety degrees halfway through, or the one that had answers that continued outside the grid. Those usually were beyond me, but not always, and conquering one was a thrill.

The NYT had become so leery of rebus puzzles that you seldom see them anymore, and when you do see them they're like this one...spoon-feeding the solutions while holding the solver's hand and murmuring encouragement. I'm waiting to see the gold star given out just for participation.

Thursday puzzles don't have to be dumbed down like this. Seeing a few outraged and frustrated rants in the comments section is a sign that you're doing it right.

The owner of that run-down duplex was the lessor of two evils.


A fun puzzle, engaging but not brain-bending tough.

CRUISIN' FOR A BRUISIN' may not have been a familiar phrase to our international solvers, but for me it was a gimme and where I cracked open the trick.

Has PHIL re-emerged and revised his forecast? I'm reading there may be another snow storm up that way on Sunday.

I enjoyed this one. I guess I shouldn't be surprised to see all the complaints, but... so it was on the easy side for a Thursday. So what? It was definitely a Thursday type of puzzle and a really impressive feat of construction. The rebus makes it a Thursday puzzle and that doesn't always mean that it has to be unusually tough. Oh well. Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=2/27/2005&g=100&d=A I'll shut up now. ......

Why are Thursdays so easy now? It cannot be that my solving skills have improved. If you look at Thursdays in the archive (2016ish) they are very challenging and still clever. Today‚Äôs was certainly clever. But so many of these clues are Sun/Mon/Tues level.

Question of a technical nature regarding today's puzzle.

I solve on a PC, and when I click on a clue, the clue appears in a somewhat larger font above the puzzle.  (This was very helpful when the clues were small, illegible pictures.)
In today's puzzle, two of the clues appeared differently in the two locations, incorrectly in the list of clues, but correctly when written above the puzzle.

In the list of clues, 46-Across was "Memorial Concert", re-written as "Concert souvenir", and 47-Down was "Bishop, I", re-written as "Bishop, e.g."

Did anyone else have this problem?  Might anyone know what could cause such a glitch?

A Thursday PB for me today, and right at my Monday average. It was enjoyable but not the 3D (TOUGHNUT) I look forward to on Thursdays. 18A (CRUISINFORABRUISIN) was fun and a phrase I haven‚Äôt heard since childhood. The theme jumped out immediately and helped a little too much with the fill. Hoping for a challenge tomorrow morning, but based on recent weeks, I‚Äôm afraid I‚Äôll be disappointed.

CRUISIN' FOR A BRUISIN' was clued as slang. Do people still say that? It was a favorite expression of my dad's, who used it to keep us kids in line, especially me, the family maverick. If he were still alive, he'd be 111, so that's some really old slang!!
I originally had INSIDER TRADERS for 48A, which has a shocking 7 out of 14 correct letters, so it was really hard for me to get my mind around changing it when I realized not everything was working.

Ya know, when you hit your personal best for a Thursday, and you have a 6-day streak going that started on Saturday (‚ÄºÔ∏è) and you find out that the median solve time was still 3 times faster than your personal best, and nearly everyone complains about how ridiculously easy the puzzle was, y‚Äôall kinda ruin it. üòû 

That said, we‚Äôve established here before that some of the easier puzzles come from trying to bring in new solvers (like me üôãüèº‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è!). I‚Äôm sorry, not sorry that my joy in solving the puzzles brings you so much pain. We‚Äôve also established that people just get better over time because you learn all the repetitive fill and you get better at spotting letter patterns (like me üôãüèº‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è!). 

Could some of it also be that collectively, our vocabulary level has gone down a bit? When they use words nobody has heard of, we all complain. ü§¶‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è Personally, I‚Äôm grateful to @WillShortz for doing the impossible job of trying to make this group happy. üòä And I‚Äôm grateful to be part of this community where we can all argue with one another, and still come together, differences and all, to enjoy one of life‚Äôs simple (at times, too simple) pleasures. ‚ù§Ô∏è

I‚Äôm still confused why ‚ÄúS‚Äù is supposed to be the lesser of two evils. I get it that it‚Äôs in the word ‚ÄúSIN‚Äù  (the letter in one evil?) but if that‚Äôs the payoff for the revealer, it‚Äôs a weak one.
Yay, a rebus!!

New PB for Thursday at 15:37! Although it looks as though this puzzle was very easy for a lot of people, I‚Äôm just happy with myself that I figured out a rebus for the first time without having to read the tips/hints article. A very enjoyable Thursday puzzle!

I‚Äôve been doing the NYT crossword for, oh, about fifty years now. I gotta say I did not solve this thinking, ‚ÄúOh, easy, bah humbug.‚Äù I solved this thinking, ‚ÄúOoh, clever theme, enjoyable solve, yay!‚Äù

I know CRUISIN FOR A BRUISIN from the outro of Pink Floyd‚Äôs Money. A female utters the phrase but it‚Äôs kinda buried. I do wish the constructor used EVIL as the rebus instead of SIN, to make it a little more on the nose. I did enjoy this one and was glad I didn‚Äôt have to struggle with it too much. I could not figure out the revealer before getting there.¬† What I was thinking was BIG SIN, LITTLE SIN???¬† What does that mean?¬† I almost clapped my hands¬†with glee when I saw THE LESSER OF TWO EVILS.¬† That's about the best and most amusing revealer I've ever seen.¬† Kudos!

Re:¬† SINGS IN THE SHOWER.¬† Too funny.¬† I don't sing in the shower because I don't take showers, but I do sing in the bathtub.¬† I've never used a shampoo¬†bottle as a microphone and I'm quite sure I never will.¬† Why on earth would I need a shampoo bottle?¬† You don't need one either, shower-singer.
¬†¬†
Lovely embedding of the SINS, both big and small.¬† No junk.¬† A delightful puzzle.

Not quite as easy as for some - I tripped up over the gas clue; now that I remember SASS I need to do the same with gas and gallons instead of petrol and litres. Slowed down by KEG, SILL (a window apron?), some names and BLOWS.

Fans of my solving -- and they are legion -- will be delighted to learn that I finished this puzzle faster than I have ever finished any Thursday puzzle. I'm down to a record fourteen seconds personal best for Thursdays. Obviously the Monday times are quicker, six seconds is my PB;  but there were some hitches today with the rebi and all. 
I think that it's time to start an admiration society of me. I wouldn't be the one to suggest it, I'm too modest for that, but I'm putting it out there in case someone with organizational skills and nothing but time on their hands wants to take up the challenge. 
It isn't easy. You'll have to manage the many thousands who want access to interviews or just time spent with me. Be strong. 
It puts me in a reflective mood: for a long time I wasn't really sure what the purpose of the internet is, at least for me -- or what the purpose of a comment section in general or this NYT crossword comment section might be. 
Now I know that the point of the whole thing is for others to boost my fragile ego on flimsy grounds, with no evidence to support my dubious claims. 
That's right, isn't it? Have I misunderstood?

I‚Äôm In my local ShopRite, which is the dominant supermarket around here. 

Of the four brands they carry, three call elbow macaroni ‚Äúelbows‚Äù; the other calls it ‚Äúelbow macaroni.‚Äù

Two of the four brands sell ‚Äúfarfalle‚Äù; the other two sell ‚Äúbow ties‚Äù or ‚Äúbowties.‚Äù  And as a bonus, the family shopping together in the aisle were discussing ‚Äúbow ties,‚Äù without mentioning ‚Äúfarfalle‚Äù at all. Don‚Äôt know whether they were Italian. But I do know that my autocorrect wants ‚Äúfarfalle‚Äù to be ‚Äúfatally.‚Äù

I got to point out however, and with all due respect to Ms. Jett  who's a mighty fine rocker, that Joan Jett is no punk.
That was not a TOUGH NUT to crack - very gentle cluing. But at least it was a rebus. "Up and ATOM" was just the right amount of silly for me.

I enjoy these puzzles when they're on the easier side, and when they're on the harder side.   When they're on the easier side, I'm obsessed for a shorter duration.  Then they're on the harder side, the enjoyment of suddenly seeing a previously unimaginable answer is terrific.

I'm up to a year of continuous solving, although I had to work backward from when I restarted, just after tax time last year, to Thu-Sun for blue stars.  I feel like I'm somewhere between apprentice and journeyman.

I admire all the terrific solvers who take the time to post and answer, and the constructors, and frankly, the NYT for having this whole endeavor.  

Seems to be a moneymaker, but, to me, amazing it has survived all the declines in readership and literacy.  It doesn't seem to me at all to be purely about money, but more dominantly, about a love of words and silly, punny, and sometimes clever wordplay.  Thanks to all.

I am not taking a side in the argument about whether the Times is making puzzles easier as part of monetization (print journalism is in so much trouble), but have others noticed that the annoying ad now offers adding FOUR people to your subscription instead of THREE?

All the puzzles I do are entertaining and so good for my aging brain. I am never inclined to complain about any puzzles, whether it seems too easy or too hard for the day it's on.  Gosh almighty, we have enough things these days to be upset and annoyed about. Puzzles are pure joy and distraction, at least they are for me.
Thanks to the whole team and to Sam for a great column, as always.

Anyhow, gotta run... I've promises to keep and sins to make before I sleep. Har!

In general, the clergy in our denomination seemed more liberal than the laity and that didn't always translate well into neighborhood arguments. We'd be hurling Bible quotes at each other.

a/ the shampoo bottle
immersed in the river

makes the sound of the river
the colorful plastic

A SIN tyro walked into a SIN S-HOP, and began browsing around. The PROprietor asked him: "What are your deSIRES?" to which he answered, "Well, as a SILLy beginner, I'm gOWEN slow. Maybe a BLIP of Envy, and a small PIECE of Sloth?"
After  a moment's consideration, he continued, "Actually, do you rent as well as sell? Then I could be a LESSoR OF TWO EVILS!"

@SP

Absolutely agree and I don't think it's elitist to want a proper challenge. I remember doing the puzzles in the 1990s. Different world altogether.

@SP

Coincidentally, I did the June 4th 2016 puzzle on Monday.  Not only did it take me far longer than recent Saturday puzzles, but I finished with one wrong box (the crossing of 37 A and 28 D).  That hasn't happened to me in a few years.  I should have known 28 D, but 37 A was just so tempting.

Most striking, was the tenor of the comments.  No whining!  The defeated solvers just chalked it up to not being up to the task.  

So, maybe the solving public has changed.  Some people just want a "gold star", but they really don't want to work at improving their skills.  Their failure has to be someone else's fault.

I better stop now.

@Nancy J.

I‚Äôve noticed this in the world of video games, too. Mainstream games have gotten easier and easier, and the younger generation often watches videos of other people playing games instead of playing themselves. That way, there‚Äôs no chance of losing. Definitely feels like there‚Äôs some ego-driven fear of failure in the air.

@Teresa
Everything, EVERYTHING! is about subscriptions, from here on out.

@SP
I have to agree.

For the record, I do have respect for the constructors. I have tried, and failed, to construct my own crossword, so I know how hard it is. I'm thankful to all constructors for giving me these puzzles.

But the difficulty of the puzzles has been on a very obvious downward trend for a while now. Most of the problem seems to be in the cluing, which in my mind is the easiest thing to fix: no need to redo the grid, just think up a trickier clue.

I like a challenge, and I think most of the people here do as well. These days, a challenging Saturday is the exception, not the norm. Thursday's tricks fall right into place instead of taking time to suss out. I'm getting bored.

@jennie

A puzzle isn't a "take it or leave it" proposition.  The crossword editors work with constructors to improve their original submissions, and they can (and do) suggest alternative clues. 

It's the clueing that determine the difficulty of the puzzle - the existence of easy mode for Friday puzzles demonstrates that.  If a difficult puzzle can be made easy by more straightforward clues, then the opposite is also true: an easier puzzle can be make harder with more subtle or trickier clues.  It's up to the editors to determine what level of cluing is appropriate for a particular day of the week.

Personally, I'm OK with an occasional easier puzzle - as long as it's only every now and then. It's the overall trend towards consistently easier puzzles in the second half of the week that I find disquieting. I like variety and definitely want challenging puzzles to be part of the mix. And that's up to the editors.

jennie,

commentBody:
@Cherry

‚ÄúPersonally, I‚Äôm grateful to @WillShortz for doing the impossible job of trying to make this group happy.‚Äù

Of course it would be impossible to make *everyone* happy, but IMO the day-of-week difficulty progression that Shortz developed hit about as broad of a sweet spot as possible.

At the moment, from my perspective, the editors are cannibalizing the brand/reputation that they developed over the course of several decades, in order to attract as many new solvers as possible in the short term. For a while, this may work nicely, as I‚Äôm sure it boosts ‚Äúengagement‚Äù for lots of newer solvers to see themselves tackle the much-feared late-week puzzles.

But here‚Äôs the thing: once Thursdays have stopped being genuinely tricky, and Fridays and Saturdays genuinely hard, for a long enough time, the reputations associated with those days will fade away as a memory of a bygone era, and people such as yourself will no longer feel a sense of pride for finishing ‚Äúan NYT Saturday puzzle‚Äù without assistance.

Not sure where things go from there‚Ä¶

@Susan E
I didn‚Äôt mean to say that people in this group don‚Äôt celebrate other‚Äôs successes because it‚Äôs clear that people are genuinely excited when someone gets a PB or gets their first long streak.üéâ But when there is so much complaining about how easy the puzzles have become due to the editors ‚Äúdumbing them down,‚Äù as some would say, it seems implied that y‚Äôall don‚Äôt want us here because we ‚Äúruined it‚Äù for you. To me, when Shortz expanded the number of proper nouns, brand names, and cultural references into the puzzles, it greatly expanded the pool of words constructors could use. Personally, I would be bored to tears if the puzzle was just puns and wordplay and black diamond vocabulary. Shortz made me think I could actually solve the cr√®me de la cr√®me of crossword puzzles. And I love the daily progression because it gives me a goal to shoot for. It pushes me to learn new things like state capitals and river names and musical terms. After 4 years, I have become a Tuesday/ Wednesday solver, and I‚Äôm proud of that. Thank you, Mr. Shortz! ‚ù§Ô∏è

@Cherry
It's fine to feel like you solved it, but as a beginner, you aren't expected to solve anything easily.

For instance, I wouldn't lace up skates for the first time, try to play in the NHL, and get mad when I couldn't keep up. I would practice at the junior level until I got good enough to advance.

In the same way, when I started out, I could only complete Mondays, and even then I'd look up what I could. I then went back through the archive, doing only Mondays, and once I became proficient, I'd move on to Tuesdays. I think it took me over a year to get into Saturdays.
@Fred Katz The word ‚Äúsin‚Äù goes in the circle, so it‚Äôs a little sin, as opposed to the full-sized ‚Äúsin‚Äù in the shaded boxes.

@Fred Katz It‚Äôs not just S, those are rebus squares. It‚Äôs SIN again squished into one square i.e. smaller. So there are two ‚Äúevils‚Äù so to speak - SIN spelled out in the grey squares, and the smaller (or ‚Äúlesser‚Äù) SIN in the rebus squares. It‚Äôs explained in the column.

Fred,
The software [usually] accepts the first letter of a rebus as a solution for the square. It's supposed to be SIN in one box.
Squishing the word into one box (as opposed to having it in three shaded boxes) is the lesser of two evils.

@Anonymous 
Thanks for your note. 
Exiting my lampoon ingpersona: I wouldn't take my comments as being reflective of some thorough read of the NYT crossword comments section. 
I only visit sporadically, I don't know new-timers from old-timers, and I have no set views on the level of difficulty of puzzles, or about comments regarding that subject. 
To answer your implied question, what I am musing about (certainly in lampoon fashion, but it's a musing), is the general internet and perhaps even societal trend toward increased bragging. 
As a sports fan I see a lot of commentary that looks like "My team is better than yours, this proves that I am right and you are wrong, I am good and you are loathsome." 
And of course we see this sort of attitude in much more consequential domains of human experience -- my people are better, my country is so yours is loathsome, and so on. 
I find the crossword comments section so benign an example of all this that the lampoon is all the more tempting, because in my view, only a fool gets all het up about a crossword puzzle. 
I hope that this is a section peopled with folks armed with sufficient critical thinking to identify a lampoon. If not here, i don't know where to look. 
My purpose in posting, if a morning jest can be said to have anything so noble as a purpose, was to amuse, and perhaps to remind us all not to take ourselves too seriously.

@Asher B.
Delightfully amused and certainly not taking myself too seriously. What a wonderfully witty commentary. Loved it. Thanks for making my day! :-)

@Asher B.

Oh, I‚Äôm certainly not bothered by your posts (which, by the way, are unmistakably written in jest).

But I guess the point of my response (and the implied, mostly rhetorical question ‚Äî though thanks for the detailed explanation!) is that I doubt *anyone* would have a problem with your posts, even if their playfulness was less obvious‚Ä¶for the simple reason that I don‚Äôt think anyone here is likely to consider their own comments to be your intended target.

I mean, perhaps some of the newbies I mentioned (who come here to cheerfully share their sense of accomplishment with a group of presumed crossword enthusiasts) would read your parodies with a self-conscious awareness that their own posts could be construed as bragging‚Ä¶but almost certainly none of the people complaining about how the puzzles have gotten way too easy would feel that way.

Over the last couple years, I‚Äôve noticed that newer participants sometimes *do* interpret regular commenters as ‚Äúbragging‚Äù (or otherwise trying to convey a sense of personal superiority) when they moan about how the late-week puzzles have become too easy. And this is always interesting to me, because I think it‚Äôs a total misread, perhaps a projection of their own insecurity about their skill level as a nascent solver‚Ä¶or something.

Anyway, it‚Äôs been a cognitively taxing work week for me, and I‚Äôm having a hard time focusing today. Hence all the typing over here.
